intro: Commiphora gardoensis, commonly known as the Gardoensis myrrh tree, is a shrub or small tree native to the dry regions of the Sahara and the Arabian Peninsula. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes frankincense and myrrh-producing species. The plant is characterized by its aromatic resinous exudates, which have been historically used in traditional medicine and incense. Its leaves are typically opposite, ovate, and have a leathery texture. The tree thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing on rocky soils and in coastal areas.
